Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: The Local Structures and Politics of a Developing Short-Term Rental Market

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
In 2008, on the heels of the financial crisis, a set of crowd-sourcing platforms (Airbnb, Uber, Lyft, etc.) emerged forming what is now estimated to be a multi-billion dollar industry, often described as the sharing economy. Because companies in the sharing economy span a range of services, and because their platforms have become hugely popular, local actors and organizations are now in a political struggle over the implications for other markets and regulatory policy. Such contentious politics have brought into question the viability of sharing economy platforms as city policymakers consider revising local regulations to accommodate the platforms or in some cases, banning them wholly. Most research on the development of new markets focuses either on the social structures that facilitate a market's emergence or on the politics involved to adapt it to existing norms and rules. This project synthesizes the two different perspectives to examine how one of the largest markets in the sharing economy, the short-term rental or ?home-sharing? sector, develops in the context of other local structures and politics. Findings from this research will show new configurations of power emerging from local sharing economy markets. These findings will also contribute to public conversation and policy discussions on the sharing economy, market regulation, lobbying and municipal government transparency.

The research combines the richness of qualitative investigation with the scope of computational and quantitative methods. Specifically, it analyzes quantitative data from short-term rental websites, the Census, nonprofit organizations, and hotels for 300 U.S. cities and metropolitan areas. It will also use new and original data collected by the researchers, including a dataset on municipal budgets and short-term rental ordinances as well as interview, historical, and participant observation data from a case study of short-term rentals in Los Angeles. In doing so, it extends scholarly understandings of markets to account for the ways in which the local and organizational contexts in which markets emerge also shape the politics over their regulation. Additionally, it considers the distinct resource and political constituency of sharing economy markets--the crowd--in these processes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
INTELLECTUAL MERIT     

            The research supported by this grant explores how local environments shape market politics, using an original dataset combining Airbnb listings, demographic data from the American Community Survey, nonprofit data from the National Center of Charitable Statistics, and hand-coded municipal ordinances regulating short-term rentals as well as a qualitative case study of Los Angeles. The funds were used to hire a team of undergraduate and graduate researchers who explored 277 municipal websites and coded 50 short-term rental ordinances as well as to transcribe the 27 interviews that were collected throughout the research period. These data will form the basis of an analysis of how local opportunities and constraints shape policies that regulate short-term rental markets.

            Research examining market formation typically focuses on one of two phases: 1) the emergence of market structures or 2) the institutionalization of those structures through politics. Synthesizing these two perspectives, I argue that the very resources and schema that facilitate the rise of these marketplaces—found in existing markets, organizations, and communities—also form the politics over their institutionalization. I incorporate theories on urban community and politics to emphasize the contingencies of place—that is, local resources, local schema, local allies, and local politics—often overlooked each of these research areas. By doing so, I hope to contribute to a call within the markets literature to examine the “autocatalytic” process (Padgett and Powell 2012) by which overlapping social systems (in this case, commodity exchange, organizational fields, and local community) create markets. Furthermore, I to empirical and conceptual understanding of the newly emergent sharing economy. Recently, a call was made to understand the implications of “crowd technologies” like the sharing economy for other more established domains (Powell 2016). I heed this call, showing how the particular and unusual resource constituency of these markets, users, comes to have effects on the domains of other markets, political advocacy, and policymaking.

 

BROADER IMPACTS

            The emergence of the sharing economy has constituted new forms of social organization that are dramatically shifting economic exchange and policymaking that has consequences for the political power of civic actors and the corporation. The funds contributed to this project have resulted in tangible data that illuminate these new configurations of power. Most of the funds were used for undergraduate and graduate research assistance that created the dataset on short-term rental ordinances. These data, along with select interviews from this study, will be made publicly available, contributing to both increased transparency about these political processes and future academic research. This research experience has also hopefully contributed to training a future cohort of academic researchers on data collection and analysis.

            Additionally, through conferences, papers, policy reports, opinion pieces, and eventually, a published book on the findings from this project, I hope to illuminate how the sharing economy creates new alliances among political actors (incumbents, challengers, and local communities and organizations) who have a stake in these markets. Such findings will hopefully contribute to future policy discussions, not just about the short-term rental policies themselves, but also campaign finance, lobbying and municipal government transparency policy issues.

 


Last Modified: 02/18/2020
Modified by: Yotala Oszkay Febres-Cordero
